title: Wick museum set for another busy year
story: &nbspIan Leith, chairman of the Wick SocietyWICK Heritage Museum is on course for another bumper year of visitors from around the world &ndash while at the same time the volunteers who run it are keen to welcome more people from the local area.&nbspIan Leith, chairman of the Wick Society, made the plea after being re-elected to the post at the annual general meeting on Thursday night.&ldquoIn the open season last year we had in excess of 5000 people, which was a good bit up on previous years, and this year looks as though it&rsquos heading very much the same way, Mr Leith said. &ldquoIt&rsquos busy, with a lot of tourists coming in. We&rsquore getting a lot of Australians in at the moment.&ldquoOne thing we would like to get more of is local people. It&rsquos great that we get these visitors from all over the world, and many of them have Caithness connections and they come on that basis, but it would be nice to get more local people.&ldquoOur open day on January 2 was a good start in that respect because it opened the door to people from the local area to come and see what we have.&ldquoA number have come back on the basis of that.&ldquoThe local people are very supportive of the Wick Society. Everything in this museum is donated by people who either live locally or have connections with this place.&ldquoI mentioned at the AGM about the amount of donations that we get in monetary terms. That&rsquos considerable, from local businesses and local people. Some of those are also in-kind donations, certainly in terms of the boat section &ndash they get quite a lot of in-kind help from businesses around the harbour.&ldquoSo, while we would like more local people to come in through our doors and appreciate what we&rsquove got here, it&rsquos not a criticism of the local people because they are very, very supportive.He added: &ldquoIt&rsquos an honour to be part of the Wick Society and to be part of its development.&ldquoWe have a number of plans in place for things we want to do. We&rsquove achieved quite a lot in the last couple of years and we&rsquore looking forward to continuing that.The Wick Society will be supporting the Industrial Archaeology Conference taking place from June 22-27. It will cover many aspects of industrial heritage in Caithness, including talks, tours, an exhibition and a visit to Orkney.&ldquoWe&rsquore involved in that on two fronts, Mr Leith said. &ldquoThe Johnston photographic collection is having a display in Caithness Horizons throughout the month of June but Wick Heritage Museum will also host some of the tours as part of the conference programme.&ldquoWe will open our doors at appropriate times to let delegates see the museum.window._taboola = window._taboola || []_taboola.push({mode:'autosized-generated-2r', title: Wicks Bremner monument gets a facelift
story: A MONUMENT at Wick in memory of wreck-raiser and civil engineer James Bremner has been given a facelift.The refurbished Bremner monument with Callum Miller (centre), his son Mikie (right) and (from left) Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait, secretary John Bogle and member Charlie Bain with his dog Jet. Picture: Robert MacDonald / Northern StudiosThe memorial overlooking the town&rsquos harbour has been refurbished by John Hood &amp Son (Sculptors) and paid for by local building firm MM Miller.&nbspThe Wick Paths Group, which was instrumental in getting the work at the memorial under way, plans to place an interpretive panel at the site telling people about the work Bremner carried out.Group secretary John Bogle said: &ldquoThere are a wealth of stories about James Bremner. I&rsquom sure there are a lot of people who won&rsquot know them.He explained that only the base of the memorial, which was erected in 1903, was still to be refurbished with the interpretation panels set to complete the whole project.The path along by the memorial is on the Wick section of the John O&rsquoGroats Trail, a 147-mile route from Inverness.Mr Bogle pointed out that interpretation panels were already in place on the stretch of the trail through Wick, with one at the Trinkie. However, two existing panels are being moved to the Braehead and North Head.He said the paths were already proving popular with local people and visitors and the group is keen to provide information about the area.Mr Bogle added that the civil engineer&rsquos gravestone &ndash in the graveyard of Wick St Fergus Church &ndash had also been tidied up recently.Wick Harbour Authority chairman Willie Watt MBE said: &ldquoFor me James Bremner is one of the unsung heroes of Caithness. He is just an amazing character. Nothing was too difficult for him and he treated everybody he worked with the greatest of respect. He was a great leader and motivator.Mr Watt pointed out that one of the Wick engineer&rsquos greatest achievements was the refloating of the SS Great Britain &ndash the largest ship of its time &ndash when she ran aground off Ireland in the 1840s.He said that Mr Bremner was sent for from Wick, along with a few of his men, when other engineers had failed in one of the biggest salvage operations of that era.James Bremner (1784-1856) was born at Stain, Keiss. He was an apprentice in a Greenock shipyard and returned to Wick to establish his own shipbuilding business, constructing over 50 vessels in as many years as well as designing and building many harbours. He was involved in the construction of the breakwater at Wick harbour.A local author, John Mowat, once described Mr Bremner as &ldquothe Ulysses of the north and &ldquoour greatest Caithnessian.Mr Bremner is still remembered in Keiss with a plaque at the harbour erected by the Institution of Civil Engineers.window._taboola = window._taboola || []_taboola.push({mode:'autosized-generated-2r',
